Report of Independent Auditors
Plan Administrator
Shell Pension Plan
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of Shell Pension Plan (the Plan), an employee benefit
plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), which comprise
the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the
related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, and the
related notes (collectively referred to as the “financial statements”).
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the
net assets available for benefits of the Plan at December 31, 2024, and 2023, and the changes in
its net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United
States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are
required to be independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities in accordance
with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we
have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for
the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and
fair presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to
fraud or error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are
conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s
ability to continue as a going concern for one year after the date that the financial statements are
available to be issued.
1

Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan’s transactions that are
presented and disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the Plan’s provisions,
including maintaining sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the
benefits due or which may become due to such participants.
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole
are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report
that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute
assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will
always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material
misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve
collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.
Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in
the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial
statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we:
(cid:127) Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
(cid:127) Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether
due to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks.
Such procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and
disclosures in the financial statements.
(cid:127) Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing
an opinion on the effectiveness of the Plan’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion
is expressed.
(cid:127) Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of
significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall
presentation of the financial statements.
(cid:127) Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the
aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going
concern for a reasonable period of time.
2

We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other
matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal
control related matters that we identified during the audit.
Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
Our audits were conducted for the purpose of forming an opinion of the financial statements as a
whole. The supplemental schedules of assets (held at end of year) as of December 31, 2024, and
reportable transactions for the year then ended (referred to as the “supplemental schedules”), are
presented for purposes of additional analysis and are not a required part of the financial statements
but are supplementary information required by the Department of Labor’s Rules and Regulations
for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA. Such information is the responsibility of management
and was derived from and relates directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to
prepare the financial statements. The information has been subjected to auditing procedures
applied in the audits of the financial statements and certain additional procedures, including
comparing and reconciling such information directly to the underlying accounting and other
records used to prepare thefinancial statements or to the financial statements themselves, and other
additional procedures in accordance with GAAS.
In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental
schedules, including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the Department of
Labor’s Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
In our opinion, the information in the supplemental schedules is fairly stated, in all material
respects, in relation to the financial statements as a whole, and the form and content are presented
in conformity with the Department of Labor’s Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure
under ERISA.

December 31, 2024 and 2023
1.Plan Description
The following description of the Shell Pension Plan (the “Plan”) provides only general
information. Participants should refer to the plan document for a complete description of the Plan’s
provisions.
General
The Plan is a defined benefit plan providing retirement benefits for employees of Shell USA,
Inc. (the “Plan Sponsor”) and certain affiliated companies (“Participating Companies”). The Plan
is administered by the Board of Trustees and a Plan Administrator. All contributions to the Plan are
made by the Participating Companies. The Plan is subject to the provisions of the Employee
Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (“ERISA”), and as described more fully
in the Rules and Regulations and Trust Agreement (the “Regulations”), which govern the Plan.
The assets of the Plan are accounted for within the Shell Pension Trust (the “Trust”). The majority
of the Plan’s assets are invested pursuant to agreements with investment managers and held in
custody at The Bank of New York Mellon. However, there are other assets invested in
certain common collective trust funds, insurance contracts, private equity limited partnerships,
and real estate limited partnerships that are invested in accordance with their governing
documents and custodied outside of The Bank of New York Mellon. Fidelity Workplace
Services LLC is the recordkeeper for the Plan.
Eligibility
In general, employees of the Participating Companies who receive a regular and stated
compensation (other than a retainer) from the Participating Companies participate in the Plan.
However, leased employees, independent contractors, and certain categories of employees
(such as employees temporarily transferred from a foreign affiliated company) are not eligible.
Benefits
Normal retirement age under the Plan is age 65 with payments discounted for early retirement. In
general, benefits are based on average final compensation (“AFC”) including incentive
compensation pay, age, and accredited service. Participants are fully vested after two years, three
6

1. Plan Description (continued)
months and a day of service or upon attainment of age 65. Upon retirement, each participant
eligible for pension benefits may receive his/her pension in the form of a qualified 50% joint and
survivor annuity. A participant who has earned an accumulated percentage formula (“APF”)
benefit may elect, with the consent of his/her spouse, to have his/her benefit paid in a lump sum.
Where a retiring employee is entitled to an immediate 80-point pension, his/her pension is not
reduced to pay for the survivor annuity for his/her surviving spouse or, in the case of a single
participant, to pay for the survivor annuity for a beneficiary so long as the beneficiary is not more
than 5 years younger than the retiring single employee. A participant who accrued benefits under
the 80-point pension formula or APF may elect to leave pension benefits exceeding 50% of his/her
pension benefits to a surviving spouse or, with the consent of the surviving spouse, to another
beneficiary. In either case, his/her benefits will be reduced to cover the costs of providing an
additional survivor benefit. Employees hired or rehired after December 31, 2012, shall participate
in the APF and such employees will not have the choice to accrue benefits under the 80-point
pension formula.
Death Benefits
If a vested employee dies in active service, his/her estate or surviving spouse will receive a survivor
benefit in accordance with the following terms. If the employee had accumulated 20 or more years
of accredited service and was at least 50 years of age, or was at least 50 years of age and the sum
of his/her accredited service and years of age (fractional years to be counted) was at least 80, or
died on or after attaining normal retirement age, his/her surviving spouse will have the choice of:
(1) the APF preretirement survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point
pension formula, a preretirement 100% joint and survivor spouse’s pension; or (2) the
preretirement 100% joint and survivor spouse’s pension assuming the employee always
participated under the 80-point pension formula; or (3) the preretirement 12½% survivor’s benefit.
However, if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s
estate equal to the present value of the pension under options (1), (2), or (3) above, whichever
produces the largest payment.
The APF preretirement survivor’s benefit is a pension benefit based on 100% of the employee’s
APF lump-sum value, if any, payable at the option of the surviving spouse in the form of a lump-
sum payment or a monthly annuity for life, but, if there is no surviving spouse, payable in the form
of a lump-sum payment to the deceased employee’s estate. If the surviving spouse elects to defer
the commencement of the APF preretirement survivor’s benefit, the APF lump-sum value will be
increased to take into account monthly interest. The preretirement 100% joint and survivor
7

1. Plan Description (continued)
spouse’s pension shall be equal to the reduced pension that would have been payable to the
employee had the employee elected the 100% joint survivorship option (without the Social
Security offset and with the free 50% built in). If the employee was single, the employee’s estate
will receive the lump-sum equivalent of the preretirement 100% joint and survivor spouse’s
pension (without the Social Security offset and with the free 50% built in). The preretirement
12½% survivor’s pension is a pension equal to 12½% of the employee’s AFC but with no actuarial
adjustment for deferred commencement of the pension. If an active employee dies who has not
satisfied the age and service requirements described above but who has accumulated at least 15
years of accredited service, his/her surviving spouse will have a choice of: (1) the APF
preretirement survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula,
a preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension; or (2) the preretirement 12½% survivor’s
benefit. However, if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased
employee’s estate equal to the present value of the pension under options (1) or (2) above,
whichever produces the larger payment.
If an active employee who has not satisfied the age and service requirements described above dies
after accumulating two years, three months and a day of vesting service, his/her surviving spouse
will be entitled to the APF preretirement survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in
the 80-point pension formula, a preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension. However,
if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s estate
equal to the APF lump-sum value plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension
formula, the present value of the preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension.
If a vested employee dies who, upon his/her termination from employment, was at least 55 years
of age and had accumulated at least 20 years of service or was at least 50 years of age and the sum
of his/her accredited service and years of age (fractional years to be counted) was at least 80,
his/her surviving spouse will have the choice of: (1) the APF preretirement survivor’s benefit plus,
if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula, a preretirement 50% spouse’s
pension; or (2) the preretirement 50% spouse’s pension assuming the employee always
participated under the 80-point pension formula. However, if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-
sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s estate equal to the present value of the pension
under options (1) or (2) above, whichever produces the larger payment.
8

1.Plan Description (continued)
The preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension is a pension benefit equal to 50% of
the deferred vested or early deferred vested pension. If the surviving spouse defers the
commencement of the benefit, the benefit shall be calculated and paid on the assumption that the
employee terminated employment on the date of death and survived to the earlier of the month in
which the pension is scheduled to commence or the month in which the employee would have
attained normal retirement age. The preretirement 50% spouse’s pension is a pension benefit equal
to 50% of the gross pension that would have been payable to the employee, calculated and paid as
though the employee had retired in the month following the month in which he/she died or, if the
spouse defers commencement of the benefit, in the month in which the benefit is scheduled to
commence, but no later than the date the employee would have attained normal retirement age.
The preretirement 50% spouse’s pension is calculated without the Social Security offset.
If a vested employee dies who, upon his/her termination from employment for qualifying events
other than ill health, had not satisfied the age and service requirements described above but who
was at least 50 years of age and the sum of his/her accredited service and years of age (fractional
years to be counted) was at least 70, his/her surviving spouse will have a choice of: (1) the APF
preretirement survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula,
a preretirement 50% spouse’s pension; or (2) the preretirement 50% spouse’s pension assuming
the employee always participated under the 80-point pension formula. However, if there is no
surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s estate equal to the
present value of the pension under options (1) or (2) above, whichever produces the larger
payment.
If a vested employee dies who, upon his/her termination from employment for a qualifying event
of ill health, had not satisfied the age and service requirements described above but who was at
least 50 years of age and the sum of his/her accredited service and years of age (fractional years to
be counted) was at least 70, but who had elected to defer the commencement of his/her benefit,
his/her surviving spouse will have a choice of: (1) the APF preretirement survivor’s benefit plus,
if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula, a preretirement 50% spouse’s
pension; (2) the preretirement 50% spouse’s pension assuming the employee always participated
under the 80-point pension formula; or (3) the preretirement 12½% survivor’s pension. However,
if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s estate
equal to the present value of the pension under options (1), (2), or (3) above, whichever produces
the largest payment.
9

1. Plan Description (continued)
If a vested employee dies who, upon his/her termination from employment by virtue of qualifying
for a disability pension, had not satisfied the age and service requirements described above but
who had accumulated at least 15 years of accredited service, and who had elected to defer the
commencement of his/her benefit, his/her surviving spouse will have a choice of: (1) the APF
preretirement survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula,
a preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension; or (2) the preretirement 12½% survivor’s
pension. However, if there is no surviving spouse, a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased
employee’s estate equal to the present value of the pension under options (1) or (2) above,
whichever produces the larger payment.
If a vested employee dies who, upon his/her termination from employment, had not satisfied the
age and service requirements described above but who had accumulated at least two years, three
months and a day of vesting service, his/her surviving spouse is entitled to the APF preretirement
survivor’s benefit plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula, a
preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension. However, if there is no surviving spouse,
a lump-sum payment is made to the deceased employee’s estate equal to the APF lump-sum value
plus, if the employee participated in the 80-point pension formula, the present value of the
preretirement 50% joint and survivor spouse’s pension.
Plan Termination
Although it has not expressed any intention to do so, the Plan Sponsor has the right to discontinue
its contributions at any time and to terminate the Plan. Should the Plan be terminated, the Plan’s
assets will be used for the payment of vested benefits and other disposition in accordance with
the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (“PBGC”) and Internal Revenue Service (“IRS”)
rules. Individual benefits are guaranteed by the PBGC, subject to a specified maximum amount as
described in ERISA.
Whether all participants receive their benefits should the Plan terminate at some future time will
depend on the sufficiency, at that time, of the Plan’s net assets to provide for accumulated plan
benefits and may also depend on the financial condition of the Company and the level of benefits
guaranteed by the PBGC, as well as the priority of those benefits. Some benefits may be fully or
partially provided for by the then-existing net assets of the Plan and the PBGC guarantee, while
other benefits may not be provided for at all.
Transfer to Insurance Carrier for Annuities Purchased
On January 30, 2024, Shell USA, Inc. and State Street Global Advisors Trust Company, an
independent fiduciary of the Plan, entered into a contract agreement with The Prudential Insurance
Company of America (“Prudential”) to purchase a group annuity contract to transfer
approximately $4.9 billion of the Plan’s defined benefit pension obligation related to certain
retirees and surviving beneficiaries under the plan. The purchase of the group annuity contract
closed on February 6, 2024 and covers approximately 21,500 Shell retirees and surviving
beneficiaries. Under the group annuity contract, Prudential made an irrevocable commitment, and
10

1.Plan Description (continued)
will be solely responsible, to pay the pension benefits of each retiree and surviving beneficiary
transferred beginning with the May 2024 pension payments. The transaction does not change the
amount of pension benefits payable to retirees and surviving beneficiaries.
2.Accounting Policies
Basis of Accounting
The accompanying financial statements are prepared on the accrual basis of accounting, except
benefit payments which are recorded on a cash basis, to conform to generally accepted accounting
principles in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”).
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to
make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts in the financial statements and
accompanying notes and supplemental schedules. Actual results could differ from those estimates.
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are reported at fair value which is the price that would be received to sell an asset or
paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement
date. The Trustees determine the Plan’s valuation policies utilizing information provided by its
investment advisers and custodian. Government securities, corporate bonds and other fixed-income
securities are stated at market value based on quoted prices, if available, or estimated market values
obtained from major investment securities firms. Common and preferred stocks and short-term
investments are stated at market value based on quoted prices. Investments in fixed income and
equity commingled funds are stated at the net asset value of the trust units held by the Plan at year
end as reported in the audited financial statements of the commingled fund. Partnerships are valued
based on the fair value of partnerships investments held by the Plan at year end as reported in the
audited financial statements of the general partners.
The cost of government securities, corporate bonds and other fixed-income securities sold is
determined by specific identification. The cost of equity investments sold is determined on the
basis of average cost. Brokerage commissions, transfer taxes and other fees are added to the cost
of purchases or deducted from the proceeds of sales. Purchases and sales of securities are recorded
on a trade-date basis. Interest income is recorded on the accrual basis. Dividends are recorded on
the ex-dividend date.
Payment of Benefits
Payments to pensioners are recorded when paid.
11

3.Federal Income Tax
The Plan has received a determination letter from the IRS dated January 30, 2017, stating that the
Plan is qualified under Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code (the “Code”) and, therefore,
the related trust is exempt from taxation. Subsequent to this determination by the IRS, the Plan
was amended and restated. Once qualified, the Plan is required to operate in conformity with the
Code to maintain its qualified status. The plan administrator believes the Plan is being operated
in compliance with the applicable requirements of the Code and, therefore, believes that the
Plan, as amended and restated, is qualified and the related trust is tax exempt.
U.S. GAAP requires plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize
a tax liability (or asset) if the Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not
would not be sustained upon examination by the IRS. The plan administrator has analyzed the tax
positions taken by the Plan and has concluded that there are no uncertain positions taken or
expected to be taken. The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing jurisdictions; however, there
are currently no tax audits for the Plan for any tax periods in progress.
4.Administrative Expenses
Actuarial, audit, administration, investment manager, custodian, PBGC premiums, and other costs
related to daily plan operations are paid by the Plan or by the Plan Sponsor on the Plan’s behalf.
When expenses are paid by the Plan Sponsor on the Plan’s behalf, the Plan Sponsor is then
reimbursed by the Plan for such expenses. Unreimbursed expenses incurred by the Plan Sponsor
totaled approximately $357 thousand and approximately $361 thousand at December 31, 2024 and
2023, respectively, and are included in accounts payable. Other indirect costs (including
Trustee/Administrator salaries, office rentals and data processing expenses) are absorbed by the
Participating Companies.
5.Funding Policy
The Plan is funded entirely by the Participating Companies, which contribute such amounts as are
necessary on an actuarial basis to provide participants’ benefits and to comply with the funding
requirements of applicable law, including the Pension Protection Act of 2006 (“PPA”). Annual
contributions are actuarially calculated using the PPA funding method based upon an assumed
average compensation growth rate of 4.60% for 2024 and 2023 and an effective interest rate of
5.12% for 2024 and 5.24% for 2023. As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Plan has met the
ERISA minimum funding requirements. There were $147 million and $160 million of employer
contributions made for the 2024 and 2023 Plan years, respectively.
6.Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including future lump-sum
distributions that are attributable under the Plan’s provisions to the service employees have
rendered. Accumulated plan benefits include benefits expected to be paid to: (a) retired or
terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died, and
(c)present employees or their beneficiaries. The actuarial present value of accumulated plan
12

6.Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits (continued)
benefits is determined by an actuary from Aon Consulting, Inc. and is that amount that results from
applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated plan benefits to reflect the time value of
money (through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by means of decrements
such as for death, disability, withdrawal or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected
date of payment.

7. Derivative Financial Instruments
The Plan’s investments in certain financial instruments involve exposure different from the
amounts recognized in the financial statements. Risk may come from an imperfect correlation
between movements in the price of the instruments and the price of the underlying indices, interest
14

7.Derivative Financial Instruments (continued)
rates, and exchange rates. Risk may also arise out of illiquid secondary markets for the instruments
and/or inability of counterparties to perform.
Futures
A futures contract is an agreement between two parties to purchase (long) or sell (short) a financial
instrument at a set price on a future date. The Plan is required to pledge to the broker an amount
of cash and/or U.S. government securities equal to a percentage of the contract amount. Subsequent
payments, known as “variation margin,” are made to or received from the broker each day,
depending on the daily fluctuations in the value of the underlying security. Such changes in value
are recorded as gains or losses on a daily basis. The Plan recognizes as realized gains or losses all
amounts received or paid to effect a closing offsetting transaction or cash settlement of the contract.
The Plan invests in futures contracts primarily for the purpose of balancing market exposure
between equity and fixed income asset classes, but they are also used to adjust to the desired market
exposure (e.g., duration). The utilization of a futures contract is intended to increase or decrease
market exposure and market price volatility. There is also a risk that the market movement of such
instruments may not be in the direction forecasted.

Forward Foreign Currency Exchange Contracts
The Plan enters into forward foreign currency exchange contracts for the purpose of hedging
against foreign exchange risk arising from the Plan’s investment or anticipated investment in
securities denominated in foreign currencies. All commitments are marked-to-market daily at the
applicable translation rates and any resulting unrealized currency gains or losses are recorded in
the Plan’s financial statements. The realized gains or losses are recorded at the time the forward
contract is extinguished by entry into a closing transaction or by delivery of the currency. Risks
may arise upon entering these contracts from the potential inability of counterparties to meet the
terms of their contracts and from unanticipated movements in the value of a foreign currency
relative to the U.S. dollar.

7. Derivative Financial Instruments (continued)
Forward Commitments
The Plan trades certain securities under the terms of forward commitments, whereby the settlement
for payment and delivery occurs at a specified future date. Forward commitments are privately
negotiated transactions between the Plan and dealers. The Plan is exposed to a risk of loss due to
nonperformance by the dealers. If the intent of the Plan is to accept delivery of a security traded
under a forward purchase commitment, the commitment is recorded as a long-term purchase. For
forward purchase commitments entered into for temporary investment holding strategies for which
security settlement is not intended by the Plan, and for all forward sale commitments, changes in
the value of the commitment are recognized as unrealized gains and losses by marking the
commitment to market on a daily basis. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, there were no forward
commitment positions included in the Plan’s investments. For the year ended December 31, 2024
and 2023, there were no forward commitments gain or loss recorded in Statements of Changes in
Net Assets Available for Benefits.

8. Partnerships
The Plan invests in several partnerships. Some of these partnerships may be made through a
non-flow through entity. As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the total capital commitment for the
Plan’s investment in partnerships was $3.4 billion and $3.6 billion, respectively. As of
December 31, 2024 and 2023, the unfunded commitment for the Plan’s investment in partnerships
was $491 million and $697 million, respectively.
9. Securities Lending
The Plan’s custodian acting as lending agent is authorized to loan its securities to brokers and
dealers. Such loans are collateralized by U.S. dollar cash, securities issued or guaranteed by the
United States Government or its agencies or instrumentalities, or irrevocable letters of credit issued
by banks independent of the Borrowers. The lending agent provides the Plan with indemnification
against losses due to borrower default. The market value of the collateral held is required to be
102% of the market value of domestic securities lent and 105% of international securities lent. At
December 31, 2024 and 2023, the market value of all collateral met such minimum requirements.
Cash collateral received in connection with these loans is invested in short-term money market
instruments and fixed-income securities which are included in the Trust’s investments, recorded
at fair value, as shown on the Statements of Net Assets Available for Benefits. The Plan will bear
the risk of any deficiency in the amount of the collateral available for return to the borrower due
to any loss on the collateral invested.
The Plan receives income based on the difference between the earnings on the invested collateral
and the negotiated rebate to the borrower. The Plan continues to earn income and maintains market
exposure on the securities being lent since the securities on loan remain assets of the Plan and, as
such, are maintained on the Trust’s records.

10. Risks and Uncertainties
The Plan invests in various investment securities. Investment securities are exposed to various
risks, such as interest rate, market and credit risks. Due to the level of risk associated with certain
investment securities, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in the values of investment
securities will occur in the near term and that such change could materially affect the amounts
reported in the Statements of Net Assets Available for Benefits. Plan contributions are made and
the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are reported based on certain assumptions
pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates, and employee demographics, all of which are subject to
change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, it is at least
reasonably possible that changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term would be
material to the financial statements.
20

11.Fair Value Measurement
ASC 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, establishes a framework for measuring fair
value. That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation
techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted
quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the
lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The three levels of the fair value
hierarchy under ASC 820 are described below:
Level 1: Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets
or liabilities in active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
Level 2: Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
• Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
• Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
• Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the assets or liability;
• Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data
by correlation or other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be
observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
Level 3: Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value
measurement.
The following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for assets measured at fair
value:
Commingled Funds and Pooled Separate Accounts: Valued based on the net asset value (“NAV”)
of the trust units held by the Plan at year end as reported in the audited financial statements of the
collective trust. The NAV is used as a practical expedient to estimate fair value. The fair value is
based on the fair value of the underlying investments of the trust. Underlying securities for which
quotations are readily available are valued at the closing market quotation in the principal market
in which such securities are normally traded. Underlying securities for which quotations are not
21

11. Fair Value Measurement (continued)
readily available are valued at amortized cost, which approximates current value. Investments in
underlying funds are valued at their closing net asset value. Transactions (purchases and sales)
may occur daily and there are no redemption restrictions on these funds.
Short-Term Investments: Cash and quoted short-term instruments, including commercial paper
having 60 days or less to maturity are recorded at amortized cost, which approximates fair value.
Common and Preferred Stocks, Corporate Bonds and Government Securities: Level 1 classified
securities are valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the individual
securities are traded. Level 2 classified securities are valued utilizing such inputs as matrix pricing,
market corroborated pricing and inputs such as yield curves and indices. Level 3 classified
securities are valued utilizing the investment manager’s pricing.
Insurance Contracts: Reflected at current contract value, which estimates fair value as determined
by the insurance company.
Futures: Valued at the final settlement price set by an exchange on which they are principally
traded.
Forward Foreign Currency Contracts: Valued using WM Reuters FX closing rates. The Bank of
New York Mellon employs standard interpolation methodology based on the WM Reuters FX
rates.
Partnerships: Valued based on the fair value of partnerships investments held by the Plan at year
end as reported in the audited financial statements of the general partners. This category includes
investments in private companies held by limited partnerships, investments in private real estate,
and investments in funds pursuing alternative investment opportunities other than private equity
and real estate. These investments generally do not provide for redemption rights for their
investors. As such, the Trust must wait until the underlying assets are sold and cash proceeds are
distributed. The current portfolio of partnerships is expected to liquidate over a period of 6-14
years.
22

11. Fair Value Measurement (continued)
The methods described above may produce a fair value calculation that may not be indicative of
net realizable value or reflective of future fair values. Furthermore, while the Plan believes its
valuation methods are appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of
different methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value of certain financial instruments
could result in a different fair value measurement at the reporting date.

11.Fair Value Measurement (continued)
Changes in Fair Value Levels
The availability of observable market data is monitored to assess the appropriate classification of
financial instruments within the fair value hierarchy. Changes in economic conditions or model -
based valuation technique may require the transfer of financial instruments from one fair value
level to another. In such instances, the transfer is reported at the beginning of the reporting period.
The Plan evaluated the significance of transfers between levels based upon the nature of the
financial instrument and size of the transfer relative to total net assets available for benefits. For
the year ended December 31, 2024, there were no significant transfers out of levels 1, 2, or 3.

Severance Rate 1.5% per year for assumed long-term average of
future unknown events.
Decrement Timing Middle of year decrements, with 100% retirement
occurring at the beginning of year
Marital Assumption Husbands are assumed to be 2 years older than
their wives.
Annuity Conversion Interest Rate For APF conversion from lump sum to annuity, the
underlying interest rates as applicable for the
minimum funding purposes and maximum tax
purposes, as prescribed by the IRS.
Annuity Conversion Mortality For APF conversion from lump sum to annuity, the
IRC 417(e) mortality table for the applicable plan
year is used.
2024 Pensionable Compensation Equal to 2023 base pay rate adjusted to 2024
using the age-weighted salary scale (see Table 1),
plus actual 2024 bonuses.
Benefit and Compensation Limits Projected benefits and compensation are limited
by the current IRC section 415 maximum benefit
of $275,000 and the IRC section 401(a)(17)
compensation limit of $345,000.
Valuation of Plan Assets Smoothed fair market value of assets over the
current and prior two years, adjusted for
contributions, benefit payments, administrative
expenses, and expected earnings. The average
value of assets calculated in this manner is further
limited to not less than 90% nor more than 110%
of fair market value.
A characteristic of this method is that the
expected distribution of the value of plan assets is
skewed toward understatement relative to the
corresponding market values for expected long-
term rates of return in excess of the third segment
rate under IRC section 430(h)(2)(C)(iii).

Schedule SB Attachment (Form 5500) —2024 Plan Year
Shell Pension Plan
EIN: 13-1299890 PN: 001
Schedule SB, line 24 — Change in Actuarial Assumptions
The valuation reflects the following assumption changes:
● A change in the assumed expenses payable from the trust from $11,941,991 to $15,305,432.
● A change in the APF interest crediting rate from the 30-year Treasury Rate for September 2022 of 3.55%
to the 30-year Treasury Rate for September 2023 of 4.47%.
● A change in expected return on assets from 7.10% (limited to 5.74%) to 7.00% (limited to 5.59%).
In addition, as a result of the 2024 demographic experience study, the following assumptions were updated:
● The 80-Point retirement rates were lowered for ages 59 and 60.
● The APF retirement rates were increased for ages under 55 and lowered for ages 55-63.
● The APF withdrawal rates were increased by 1.5% for less than 4 years of service and lowered for ages
over 55.
● The severance rate was increased by 0.5%.
● The 80-Point optional payment form election changed as follows:
80-Point Eligible
Payment Form January 1, 2023 January 1, 2024
Single life annuity 10% 15%
50% Joint & Survivor 40% 30%
100% Joint & Survivor 50% 55%
● The APF timing of payment was changed from 30% immediate and 70% defer to 59 to 40% immediate
and 60% defer to age 58 or age 65 if over age 58.
● The disability rates were updated from 2018 Buck Custom Table to 75% of Standard Aon Medium
Disability Table.
Rationale for Assumptions
The rationale for each demographic assumption was the 2024 experience study performed by Aon for the
period 2021-2023. This study included discussions between Shell USA, Inc. and Aon about expectations for
the future. Shell selected the final assumptions based on these inputs.

Benefit and Compensation Limits Projected benefits and compensation are limited
by the current IRC section 415 maximum benefit
of $275,000 and the IRC section 401(a)(17)
compensation limit of $345,000.
Valuation of Plan Assets Smoothed fair market value of assets over the
current and prior two years, adjusted for
contributions, benefit payments, administrative
expenses, and expected earnings. The average
value of assets calculated in this manner is further
limited to not less than 90% nor more than 110%
of fair market value.
A characteristic of this method is that the
expected distribution of the value of plan assets is
skewed toward understatement relative to the
corresponding market values for expected long-
term rates of return in excess of the third segment
rate under IRC section 430(h)(2)(C)(iii).

Schedule SB, Part V — Summary of Plan Provisions
Effective Date January 1, 1938. Amended and Restated April 1, 2018.
Participation Immediate
Accrued Benefit
Hired or Rehired after December 31, 2012 Accumulated Percentage Formula
Last Hired prior to January 1, 2013 Annual choice to accrue benefits for each Plan Year
under either the 80-Point Pension Formula or the
Accumulated Percentage Formula
80-Point Pension Formula The regular pension is equal to the Gross Pension, minus
the Offset, plus, if applicable, the Social Security
Supplement:
Gross Pension 1.6% of Average Final Compensation multiplied by 80-
Point Service,
Offset The lesser of (1) and (2)
(1) (A) 1.5% of the employee’s Primary Social
Security benefit multiplied by the number of
years of total service the employee would have
had at his Social Security Normal Retirement
Age, up to a maximum of 50%, multiplied by
(B) a fraction not to exceed one: actual 80-point
service divided by years of total service the
employee would have had at Social Security
Normal Retirement Age.
(2) (A) 1.5% of the Social Security benefit the
employee is entitled to at age 65, multiplied by
the number of years of total service the
employee would have had at age 65, up to a
maximum of 50%, multiplied by
(B) a fraction not to exceed one: actual 80-point
service divided by years of total service the
employee would have had at age 65.

80-Point Pension Formula The regular pension is equal to the Gross Pension, minus
the Offset, plus, if applicable, the Social Security

Gross Pension 1.6% of Average Final Compensation multiplied by 80-

Offset The lesser of (1) and (2)

years of total service the employee would have

Age, up to a maximum of 50%, multiplied by
(B) a fraction not to exceed one: actual 80-point
service divided by years of total service the
employee would have had at Social Security
Normal Retirement Age.
(2) (A) 1.5% of the Social Security benefit the
employee is entitled to at age 65, multiplied by
the number of years of total service the
employee would have had at age 65, up to a
maximum of 50%, multiplied by
(B) a fraction not to exceed one: actual 80-point
service divided by years of total service the
employee would have had at age 65.

Schedule SB, line 24 — Change in Actuarial Assumptions
The valuation reflects the following assumption changes:
● A change in the assumed expenses payable from the trust from $11,941,991 to $15,305,432.
● A change in the APF interest crediting rate from the 30-year Treasury Rate for September 2022 of 3.55%
to the 30-year Treasury Rate for September 2023 of 4.47%.
● A change in expected return on assets from 7.10% (limited to 5.74%) to 7.00% (limited to 5.59%).
In addition, as a result of the 2024 demographic experience study, the following assumptions were updated:
● The 80-Point retirement rates were lowered for ages 59 and 60.
● The APF retirement rates were increased for ages under 55 and lowered for ages 55-63.
● The APF withdrawal rates were increased by 1.5% for less than 4 years of service and lowered for ages
over 55.
● The severance rate was increased by 0.5%.
● The 80-Point optional payment form election changed as follows:
80-Point Eligible
Payment Form January 1, 2023 January 1, 2024
Single life annuity 10% 15%
50% Joint & Survivor 40% 30%
100% Joint & Survivor 50% 55%
● The APF timing of payment was changed from 30% immediate and 70% defer to 59 to 40% immediate
and 60% defer to age 58 or age 65 if over age 58.
● The disability rates were updated from 2018 Buck Custom Table to 75% of Standard Aon Medium
Disability Table.
Rationale for Assumptions
The rationale for each demographic assumption was the 2024 experience study performed by Aon for the
period 2021-2023. This study included discussions between Shell USA, Inc. and Aon about expectations for
the future. Shell selected the final assumptions based on these inputs.
